Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Calculus skills, as well as organizational ones
I reviewed all of integration and series.
general calculus
Problem solving
It helped me get a lot more critical thinking skills.
Integration and series calculations.
Everything math 115 would teach you
Calc 2 topics and skills

I gained an understanding of how to interpret certain physical phenomena in terms of the area under a curve and was thus able to understand how clever ways in integral calculus enable us to calculate quantities that were previously uncalculable.
Calculus
I learnt about how useful and powerful calculus is and there were many relevant applications to it.
The fundamentals of calculus but no idea of what to use it for.
Maybe mandatory office hours once in a while to check in would be helpful
The M/W/F classes have too little time. If each class were an hour then it would probably give more time for practice and asking the instructor for clarification on certain practice problems.

I honestly really dislike the whole "flipped classroom" idea and thought the pre-class videos were largely unhelpful. By the end of the course I didn't even watch them and instead just read the textbook, which was much more relevant to the problem sets and exams. I also felt like the practice exams were always easier than the actual exams. For some reason I always seemed to be able to do the practice exams, but then I came into the exams and found them quite difficult (maybe this is just a reflection of my own test anxiety, but I know others felt the same way and it has never been an issue for me before).
Organization.
The flipped classroom was very hard to deal with but it was a good learning experience.
I think the homework should be more similar to the exams.
I think that a major weakness was the disconnect between the flipped classroom videos and what we learn and are tested on in class. Many topics are glossed over in the videos.
My teacher didnt a good job of dividing the class into tracking time and review time along with keeping people paying attention
Flipped classrooms are much less effective in getting the lesson clearly across
This course can be improved if attention is given to students understanding these concepts and being given the space to experiment with the ideas and techniques learnt on thier own.

I hate the reverse class room it is the worst idea. Although Yale is a great college their math department is in dire need of improvement. The grading system is also very ineffective and this course is based on much memorization.
This course taught concepts through formulas and rules but I think if it were framed with more connections to what calculus is used for would have seemed more worth while.
Only if you have to take it for a requirement. Take it with Prof. Bennett.

If Professor Bennett were teaching your section, I would highly recommend. Very competent, astute, and understanding, Professor Bennett is probably one of the best math professors I've seen in a while.
not unless necessary for credit
No. I regret taking this course, and if it is not a requirement, you should not take it.
Yes
Yes, but I would recommend it only if they had a good professor because otherwise, it is difficult.
Yes if interested in maths
Take it if you have to
If anyone's taking 115, it's probably because they need to for their major, in which case, there's no way around it. Otherwise, no, don't take this class (even for "an easy QR")

If he has a fair idea of the principles used in the class before hand, I would encourage him/her to skip ahead and take 120, but if he/she hasn't it might be worth taking time to appreciate the techniques this course teaches under each chapter.
No because of how its taught unless they have to take it for their major.
Yes, I would recommend this course.
No. Id suggest they pursue other math areas. However calculus is very important to many fields so they probably have to take it.
